narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of electromagnetic forces and fields in extreme mathematically rigor. I learned how Maxwell's equations arise naturally from empirical results. I learned about the implications of Maxwell's equations; for example, the existence of electromagnetic radiation in free space and the generation of radiation from accelerating dipoles. I learned how to formulate electromagnetism in terms of potentials. Towards the end of the semester, we touched on the deep relationship between electromagnetism and relativity.
electrodynamics, magnetism, optics, etc.

Learned about electric and magnetic fields, with some interesting real-world applications. Not really focused on circuits, more on the theory. It sounds like the APHY version of E&M is more application-based, but this course had some great connections to current science.
Electricity and magnetism
I learned the fundamentals of electrodynamics.
I developed a much greater conceptual understanding of E&M, as well as some really interesting applications! Also grew more familiar with aspects of mathematics like a tensor, delta function etc.
Vector calculus, potentials, solving Laplaces equation, electro and magnetostatics, multipole expansion, maxwells equations and their solutions, optics, electromagnetic waves, gauge invariance

We learned classical E&M, including calculating the general 4-potential in the Lorentz gauge, and did some interesting calculations like: why the Bohr model fails (synchrotron radiation), why its hard to use electrons in particle accelerators (synchrotron radiation), and why conductive things tend to be shiny (not synchrotron radiation).
Built upon EM knowledge from intro classes.
First 11 chapters of Grffiths' Introduction to Electrodynamics

In this class, I learned how to quantify electromagnetic fields. In addition, I learned how to apply these theories in various physics phenomena. The course built upon itself, going from a mathematics review and building that up to explain complex electromagnetic systems.
Electrodynamics and optics
This course covered all of the integral parts of electromagnetic fields. Near the end, we also explored some interesting subtopics such as relativity and optics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course material is presented in an extremely logically and precise manner. However, sometimes too much emphasis is placed on mathematical derivations and not enough on conceptual understanding.
good class on e&m and moore is a great professor. alot of class felt like it was of derivations, but that is as much as I expected.

The textbook (Griffiths) is really great, and the professor is really good at keeping up engagement and explaining things in a clear manner. When I got to the exams, I really felt like I understood what we had covered and why, which was in part due to the layout of the textbook. Also, the problems on the problem sets were creative and had cool relations to actual lab work going on at Yale. The psets seemed pretty long some weeks, but overall I think the pacing and everything was good.
Professor Moore is fantastic, he is a great lecturer and explains concepts very clearly. I looked forward to coming to every class because he made the material interesting and understandable.
It was a very good course. Professor Moore is an incredible teacher and did a very job managing all the difficulties associated with the pandemic
Professor was super caring and engaging. The textbook was also great. Sometimes I could get lost during really long stretches of algebra in in-class proofs, though.
Strengths: very clear and consistent, great textbook, helpful professor and TAs, interesting problem sets that explore other areas of physics
Professor Moore teaches closely with the textbook, which I found to be really helpful as it meant we had two mediums to learn the material and could easily reference between them.
I thought the lectures were fantastic and incredibly informative.

Strengths: clear expectations and rigid structure from day 1, a very interesting subject and a great professor with a very soothing voice. A very no-nonsense class that you can get a lot out of if you wish. 

Weaknesses: I would definitely have made more use of the TF office hours if they were longer or more frequent (an hour a week is the lowest I've ever had for a Yale STEM class).

I think Professor Moore is an amazing professor. He was extremely talented at breaking down tough concepts and simply explaining the examples. Furthermore, I think that this course was structured well, and the material naturally built upon itself. Over time, I was amazed at how much I learned in the class. The course is tough (exams were always extremely hard), but interesting and well organized. I think something that could make the class more manageable and allow for more interaction is to have more office hour and study hall sessions.

The class is taught very closely to Griffiths which is a strength given the textbook is a great treatment of E&M. Moreover, Moore does a great job at covering the textbook and even his pset questions are super interesting and full of footnotes that show you the real world applications of what you are learning.

This class was organized very well and did a great job working parallel with the textbook. Professor Moore is as good as any physics professor at Yale in explaining complex topics and preparing very interesting lectures.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: professor used the "whiteboard" functionality very well.

The professor asked simple questions during class, which helped keep me focused. It would have been nice to have been assigned study groups or something just to be able to get to know classmates better, because I think the students are a big part of making a class enjoyable.
All that were put into practice.
A fairly typical, solid plan for Covid.

In lecture, Professor Moore used his iPad as a whiteboard to write down notes as if he was explaining it on a blackboard in real life. This was great as it made it easier for students to follow along with the lecture. As a result, I felt that this was the most normal lecture course that I took this year. Due to Zoom fatigue, it became harder through the year to pay attention, but nonetheless Professor Moore did a great job at explaining material.
Keeping the live lectures as close to a normal lecture as possible worked well. Also, the recordings were very useful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to any student who wants to understand electromagnetism on a deep level. E & M is not the most glamorous branch of physics, but it is the basis for so many other topics that it is crucial to have a strong foundation in it.
yes! required for the physics major, but david moore is just a great dude.

I would definitely recommend this course, especially as taught by David Moore. I can't pin down why his explanations are so clear (maybe because by this point we've had E&M before? But it's more [Moore?] than that), but his method of giving information is really fantastic. The lecture notes are also really great to be able to look back at.
I would absolutely recommend this course if Moore was teaching it. He makes electricity and magnetism actually understandable.
Definitely, it gives a good grasp of electrodynamics
Yes! Professor is super nice and, once you slosh through some new notation, you get to really start understanding some fun aspects of E&M!

Yes! This has been my favorite physics course so far. Professor Moore is super clear, and he always tells you where things are coming from. You basically start with some fundamental principles and work up to the very fancy and  results of electrodynamics, its super satisfying!

If you're a physics major, you'll take this. If you aren't but are looking to take a physics class, I'd say this would be a better one due to Professor Moore. The content is interesting and he teaches it well.
yes, professor Moore was probably the best physics teacher I've had at Yale
I would recommend this course.

I'm a math major who took this course without any physics background whatsoever for the B.S. degree, so I'll talk specifically to that experience. If this is you, I would say that you should only take this course if you are very comfortable with multivariable calculus (which I know most math majors are not) and integration in spherical and cylindrical coordinates. If you haven't seen E&M before it'll be very hard to have any intuition for the subject and a lot of stuff will make little to no sense (more so than in classical mechanics, perhaps less so than in quantum), so make sure to read the Griffiths along with the class (it's a fantastic textbook) from the VERY beginning. With the Griffiths, lecture, and online resources, I did not feel as conceptually lost as I expected. Be warned that the weekly p-sets can take a fair amount of time, and study the Griffiths carefully for the exams. Classical mechanics is still probably a better choice if you're going for the B.S. degree last minute, but this is genuinely a good class and a really interesting subject if you want to jump in.

I would recommend this course for physics majors and interested math majors. This class is taught and structured extremely well, which makes the course interesting. However, as with every other advanced level physics course, it is tough, so be prepared to spend time working through the material.
Yes, any student interested in physics and particularly E&M should take this class. It essentially goes through all of Griffiths and is a good overview of the subject.
Yes, I would recommend this course to all students interested in physics beyond the introductory level. This course is Yale Physics at it's best, and is worth the time and effort.
